Married and the mother of six children (four of them fully grown and two still in school), Luciana attended elementary school in Zimbabwe but couldn't continue her schooling because of her family's financial constraints.

She lives with her children, sister and two nephews, whom she supports, in a house she owns. She left Tete for Maputo when her husband's work transferred him there. She receives a monthly pension of 5.154.00mt from the Ministry of Defense. The money allows her to take care of household expenses as well as, with the help of her husband's pension, put some money into a savings account. She has never had loans with other institutions and this is her first one with Hluvuku.

Luciana plans to use the 20.000.00mt to buy construction material (nails, iron, cement, sand, stones, etc) to continue the construction of her house. She is confident in her ability to pay back this loan and plans to apply for others  in the future, to finish building her house.

loans.use: to buy construction material (nails, iron, cement, sand, stones, etc)

loans.name: James

texts.en: James is 26 years old and blessed with two children who are in school. He has been running his retail shop for five years. He runs his business in a very competitive environment. He thanks Faulu Kenya for helping to grow his business and now the business is stable. He hopes that someday, he will expand his business into wholesale. He has requested for a loan of 40,000 KES to buy sugar, maize flour, cooking oil and soda.

loans.use: To buy sugar, maize flour, cooking oil, and soda.

loans.name: Lanie

texts.en:
This is Lanie C., 50, resident of Dasmariñas, Cavite City, Philippines. She is married to Perdito, a construction worker, and mother to their child. By the grace of God, Lanie has managed to support her child's schooling. At this time, she is working hard to be able to send her child all the way through college. A dream for most Filipino parents like Lanie as she herself has been a college undergraduate and believes that a college diploma is the best inheritance parents could leave to their children.

Lanie maintains a frozen food business. She sells native delicacies like sweetened pork, spiced native sausages and others of the like. A customer's order is bought in cash by the dealer and then given to the customer with a one-week-to-pay credit. Dealer’s prices are lower than those prices offered to customers and these are the profits that dealers are counting on as their income. Her regular customers are her neighbors and the local community. She earns a minimum of PHP 300 in sales every week.

To help her continue operations of her business, she is requesting a PHP 11,000 loan. She will be utilizing the loan to buy orders for her customers. She expects a boost in her business income as she expands her business.

Lanie dreams to be able to give her child a good and high quality education through all her hard work on her business. She faithfully meets up with her co-fellowship* members to share stories of her work every week.

* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay micro finance loans.

loans.use: To buy orders for her customers.

loans.name: Josephat

texts.en:
Josephat is 36 years old and married with three children who are in school.  He owns and runs M.N.C furniture shop.  He has been running the business for ten years with three employees.  He also operates a kiosk for extra income.  He is a member of Faulu Kenya under Aheco group.  He appreciates Faulu Kenya for helping him to have enough ready made stock.  

He has requested a loan of 30,000 KES to buy timber, block boards, MDF boards and hardware materials.  He hopes to become a part of Shakers and Movers in the furniture industry in Kenya.

loans.use: To buy timber, block boards, MDF boards and hardware materials

loans.name: Esther

texts.en:
Esther is 25 years old and married with a three-year-old child.  She runs Esther’s Boutique to earn a living.  She has engaged in the business for two years.  She says that she gets a number of customers everyday.  

She is a member of Faulu Kenya under Embakasi Upendo group.  Through the group, she has been able to save her money.  She hopes to have a wholesale shop in the future.  

She has requested 25,000 KES to add to her stock of clothes and cosmetics. She believes that with additional stock, she will attract more customers.

loans.use: To add to her stock of clothes and cosmetics

loans.name: Georgina Ernesto

texts.pt:
Georgina Ernesto N. nasceu na cidade de Maputo, Província do mesmo nome, sul de Moçambique, solteira mãe de 2 filhos de 4 e 7 anos de idade vão a escola. Freqüenta o primeiro ano de faculdade. Vive na casa própria e não sustenta mais ninguém para além dos filhos. 

Nunca saiu da terra natal, é comerciante e dona do negócio ha mais de 10 anos, vende mais extensões de cabelo. Consegue um rendimento de cerca de 10.000.00mt por mês que aplica nas despesas de casa e ainda poupa algum na sua conta bancaria (Millenium Bim).

Ja teve empréstimo no banco Tchuma e decidiu não continuar, conheceu a Hluvuku através de uma cliente vizinha que também é cliente desta instituição. Este é o seu primeiro empréstimo no valor de 17.000.00mt com o qual pretende comprar produtos (extensões de cabelo e produtos cabeleireiros) para aumentar a quantidade da sua mercadoria.

No futuro quer solicitar mais um empréstimo para a conclusão da sua casa. Esta confiante que vai pagar sem nenhum problema.
texts.en:
Georgina Ernesto N. was born in Maputo, in Southern Mozambique. She is the single mom of two sons, ages 4 and 7, who are in school. She is attending her first year of college. She lives with her children in a house they own. She's never left Maputo.

For the past four years she has been running a hair salon business, where she sells hair extensions and products. She makes 10.000.00mt per month and, after taking care of household expenses, is able to save some money at Millenium Bim bank.

Georgina has had a loan with Tchuma Bank before. She learned about Hluvuku from a neighbor friend who is a client of the institution. This is her first loan with Hluvuku and she plans to use the 17.000.00mt to buy more products for her salon (hair extensions, creams, etc).

She's confident in her ability to pay back this loan and plans to apply for more loans in the future, to finish building her house.

loans.use: to buy more products for her hair salon (hair extensions, hair products, etc)

loans.name: Melisa Ethefu

texts.en:
Melisa Ethefu O. is a 38-year-old skilled and experienced business lady who has longstanding relationships with her school and pupils. She operates her own private school where she earns a living. She is married to Mahero Mutsoli; they have three children aged 17 years, 13 years and six years respectively.

Melisa started her business in 2000 with Ksh.20,000 start-up capital, working in Eldoret town. She has been in this business for the past ten years with an income of Kshs.247,000 per month.

She was introduced to KADET LTD by a credit officer and she is applying for her first loan of Kshs.40,000 with KADET LTD. With her loan she plans to build more classrooms and make desks.

loans.use: To build more classrooms and make desks

loans.name: Mary

texts.en:
Mary is a 36-year-old member of Funga Leso group.  She has been operating a grocery shop for seven months where she sells fruits, vegetables, cereals and milk.   Mary is a hardworking mother of two and she hopes to improve her business in the future.  She has learned how to save her money for personal needs.  She thanks Faulu Kenya for the support. 

She has requested 20,000 KES to buy more vegetables, milk and cereals to sell.

loans.use: To purchase vegetables, milk and cereals

loans.name: Amarzaya

texts.en:
Amarzaya G., age 29, lives with her husband and six-year-old daughter in Tuv, the central province of Mongolia. They live together in a ger (traditional Mongolian tent home) on a small plot of land. Her daughter attends a local primary school. Her husband is a builder, but currently helps out Amarzaya's business by transporting meats from the countryside using his truck. 

Amarzaya operates a meat trading business in a rented stall at Bayanhaan market, the one of local markets in the city. She has been operating this business for the last six years and has become quite a successful businesswoman. She purchases meat at wholesale prices from the countryside. Over the years, she has gained not only much experience but also a wide customer base. 

Amarzaya is a modest, generous and hardworking woman. She hopes to expand her business and improve her living conditions by building a new winter house for her family in the future. She is requesting a 1,500,000 MNT loan to purchase and preserve a large amount of meat at wholesale prices for her business.

loans.use: To purchase and preserve a large amount of meat

loans.name: Salome Wangari

texts.en:
Salome has been running her beauty salon in Naivasha town for the last three years.  She is 27 years old, married to Joseph Njoroge, and they have one child.

She was introduced to KADET LTD by her friend and this will be her first loan.  She is planning to open a barber shop and employ someone else to run it, so she will use the cash to buy equipment for the barber shop.

In the future, Salome hopes to own a number of salons in town.

loans.use: To buy equipment for her shop.

loans.name: Daniel

texts.en:
Daniel is a 28-year-old man.  He runs a cafeteria and also does outside catering to earn a living.  He joined Faulu Kenya under Pastures Self Help group and he has developed a good savings plan.  Daniel has been running his business for five years in a very competitive environment.  He hopes to own a chain of cafeterias in the future.  

Daniel has requested 20,000 KES to buy cooking fat, rice and wheat flour.

loans.use: To buy cooking fat, rice and wheat flour

loans.name: Peter

texts.en:
Peter is 31 years old and married with three children.  He has been operating Mama Safi shop (a general store) to earn a living.  His business is located in the Kwa Reuben slums, so most of his customers are low-income earners.  His wife assists him in running the business because he is otherwise employed.  In fact, he was not available for the photo so we took his wife’s photo at the business premises.  

Peter has asked for his first loan of 20,000 KES to enlarge his business premises.  He says that he is expecting that the loan will help him to improve his status.

loans.use: To enlarge his business premises

loans.name: Antonio

texts.pt:
Antônio M. nasceu na cidade da M., Província de Maputo, sul de Moçambique, pai de 4 filhos dos quais 3 vão a escola. Fez 10ª classe pretende continuar no futuro. Vive na casa própria com a sua família e sustenta 2 sobrinhos que vivem com ele. 

Saiu de M. para o bairro da Machava quando constituiu sua família. Trabalha como docente e funcionário permanente do Ministério de Educação, tem um salario de 4.392.00mt por mês que aplica nas despesas de casa e ainda consegue poupar algum na sua conta bancaria (Millenium Bim).

Nunca teve empréstimo em outros bancos, conheceu a Hluvuku através de colegas de serviço que já são clientes desta instituição. Este é o seu primeiro empréstimo no valor de 10.000.00mt com o qual pretende comprar material de construção (cimento, ferro, barrotes, pedra, areia e outros) para dar continuidade com a construção da sua residência.

Esta confiante que vai pagar sem nenhum problema e pedir um novo empréstimo para concluir sua casa.
texts.en:
Antônio M. was born in M., Maputo, in Southern Mozambique. He is the father of four children, three of whom are in school. His studies were interrupted when he was in 10th Grade, but he hopes to go back to school one day. He lives with his family and two nephews in a house they own.

He moved to the neighborhood of Machava when he started his family. Employed by the Ministry of Education, Antônio currently works as a teacher, earning a monthly salary of 4.392.00mt. His salary allows him to pay for all the household expenses as well as put some money into a savings account at Millenium Bim Bank.

He learned about Hkuvuku from a co-worker, and this is his first loan. He plans to use the 10.000.00mt to buy construction material (cement, iron, beams, stones, sand, etc) to continue building his house.

He's confident in his ability to pay back this loan and plans to apply for others in the future, to finish his house.

loans.use: to buy construction material (cement, iron, beams, stones, sand, etc)

loans.name: Sekoye Masayaton

texts.en:
Sekeyo has been farming in Naivasha town since 2003.  He is 48 years old, married to Senkoi Sayaton, and they have 14 children.

He was introduced to KADET LTD by his friend, and this will be his second loan. He plans to use the cash to plant potatoes and buy cattle which he will sell later at a profit.

Sekoye plans to own his own tractor in the future.

loans.use: To plant potatoes and buy cattle which he will sell later at a profit.

loans.name: Tserensodnom

texts.en:
Tserensodnom O. lives with his wife and two children in Arhangai province in Mongolia. He and his family live together in a ger, a traditional Mongolian nomadic tent. Both his children attend a local secondary school while his wife works as a teacher in the school. He used to be in the monastery as a lama between 2004 and 2006. 

He has been operating a milk and dairy product trading business for the last four years with a working capital of 200,000 MNT, and has built a stable and successful operation. After years of successful operation, he has managed to increase his working capital to a level exceeding 2,000,000 MNT today. Since beginning his business, he has been able not only to provide for his family, but he has also been able to purchase a new car for himself. 

Tserensodnom is requesting a 500,000 MNT loan to purchase milk and fermented milk for his business.

loans.use: To purchase milk and fermented milk

loans.name: Alicia

texts.en:
This is Alicia C., 50, resident of Dasmariñas, Cavite City, Philippines. She has a child currently enrolled in college. By the grace of God, Alicia has managed to support her child's schooling up to college level. At this time, she is working hard to continually provide income for their every day expenses.

Alicia operates a piggery. Basically, she buys piglets, raises them for meat, and when they are ready for slaughter, sells to customers, mostly people who own meat shops and those who sell pork meat in the market. Her store is located adjacent to her house. Her regular customers are her neighbors and the local community.  She earns a minimum of $9 in sales every day.

To help her continue operations of her business, she is requesting a 15,000 PHP loan. She will be utilizing the loan to buy more piglets to be sold. She expects a boost in her business income as she expands her business. 
 
Alicia dreams of being able to renovate her house soon, with all of her work with the business. She faithfully meets up with her co-fellowship* members to share stories of her work every week.

* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay Micro-Finance loans.

loans.use: buy more piglets to be sold, including feeds and vitamins for them

loans.name: Joseph Soine

texts.en:
Joseph, 27 years old, has practiced farming in Naivasha town since 2003.  He sells his products in the local market where he fetches a tidy sum.

He was introduced to KADET LTD by a friend and this will be his second loan.  He plans to use the cash to harvest the peas which he planted early this year and also to buy wheat seedlings which he plans to plant after he harvests the peas. 

Joseph hopes to venture into commercial farming in the near future.

loans.use: To harvest peas in the farm and buy wheat seedlings for planting.

loans.name: Liliash

texts.en: Liliash B. is currently in the business of selling mixed goods and is requesting a loan to stock more goods to sell.  Liliash is 46 years old and is widowed. She has five children and currently only two of her children are in school.  With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to open up a shop.

loans.use: To stock more goods to sell

loans.name: Mercedita

texts.en:
This is Mercedita C., 46, resident of Dasmariñas, Cavite City, Philippines. She is married to Ponciano C. and the mother to a young school-aged child and to their youngest who is just able to toddle at home. By the grace of God, Mercedita has managed to support her child's schooling. At this time, she is working hard to continually provide income for their everyday expenses.

Mercedita operates a variety store and does sideline work doing direct selling of clothing, footwear and cosmetics. In the Philippines, a variety store is basically a small convenience store, which retails groceries, toiletries and beverages piecemeal to the local neighborhood. It is the place to go to buy one sachet of shampoo, 5 PHP-worth of cooking oil, or an egg. She earns by getting supplies at wholesale prices and selling at piece rate.  Her store is located adjacent to her house and her regular customers are her neighbors and the local community.  She earns a minimum of $7 in sales every day.

To help her continue operations of her business, she is requesting an 18,000 PHP loan. She will be utilizing the loan to buy more quantities of products, like groceries, toiletries and beverages, to expand her product inventory. She expects a boost in her business income as she expands her business. 
 
Mercedita dreams of being able to renovate her house soon, with all of her work with the business. She faithfully meets up with her co-fellowship* members to share stories of her work every week.

* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay Micro Finance loans.

loans.use: buy more quantities of products like groceries, toiletries and beverages to expand her product inventory

loans.name: Vandanduger

texts.en:
Vandanduger T. is 31 years old and lives with his wife and one son in Arhangai province, Mongolia, in a ger, a traditional Mongolian nomadic tent. His son attends a local kindergarten while his wife works as a teacher in the local school. 

Vandanduger has been operating a taxi service since 2000 and started to operate a raw material trading business in 2004 in addition to his taxi service. In the beginning, his working capital was 400,000 MNT, and after years of successful operation he has gained many permanent customers as well as much experience in both businesses. He has managed to increase his working capital to a level exceeding 3,000,000 MNT today. 

He purchases his raw materials from the countryside using his own car and resells at the local market for profits. His earnings have enabled him to make a complete re-construction of his home. Vandanduger is a very modest man. He is requesting a 2,600,000 MNT loan to buy more raw materials to resell for expansion of both of his businesses.

loans.use: To buy more raw materials to sell

loans.name: Stephen Onyango

texts.en:
Stephen has been repairing vehicles in Naivasha town since the year 2006.  He is 28 years old, married to Edith Auma, and they have two children.

He was introduced to KADET LTD by a friend and this will be his second loan. He paid his first loan well and in good time. He plans to use this cash to buy fiberglass materials which he uses for repairing vehicle bodies.

Stephen also hopes to be the supplier of fiberglass materials for the entire Naivasha town.

loans.use: To buy more fiberglass material for repairing vehicles.

loans.name: Christina

texts.en: Christina E. is currently in the business of selling mixed goods like tomatoes, maize flour, etc. She is requesting a loan to stock more goods to sell.  Christina is 48 years old and is widowed. She has five children and her children go to school. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to pay the school fees for her children.

loans.use: To stock more goods to sell

loans.name: Simon

texts.en: Simon N. O. is 43 years old and a member of Good Hope group registered under Faulu Kenya. He runs a furniture shop and also sells fruits to earn extra income. He has requested a loan of 15000 KES to buy timber and paints. He hopes to have a furniture show room in the future. Simon is a father of six children who go to school. He describes himself as hardworking.

loans.use: To buy timber and paints

loans.name: Viola

texts.en: Viola N. is currently in the business of selling oil, rice and sugar and is requesting a loan to stock more bags of rice and sugar to sell. Viola is 22 years old and is married. Her husband is a business man. She has three children and two of her children go to school. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to open a shop.

loans.use: To stock more bags of rice and sugar to sell

loans.name: Stella

texts.en: Stella M. has been selling cereals in Naivasha town for the last three years. She is 40 years old and is married to Timothy Muvengei. They have three children. She was introduced to KADET Ltd. by a friend, and this will be her second loan. She paid her first loan well and in good time. She plans to use this loan to buy peas, maize and beans in bulk to have enough stock to sell to her customers. In the future, Stella hopes to supply cereals to the hospitals, schools and hotels around Naivasha town.

loans.use: To add to her stock of peas, maize and beans for sale

loans.name: Abraham

texts.en:
This is Abraham B., 46, a resident of Dasmariñas, Cavite City, Philippines. He is married to Judith B., a storekeeper, and is the father of a college aged young adult and two high-schoolers. By the grace of God, Abraham has managed to support his child's schooling up to the college level. At this time, he is working hard to continually provide income for his family's every day expenses.

Abraham operates a variety store and also an egg wholesaling and retailing business. He imports eggs from poultry farms, brings them to the capital and then sells them for a few pesos profit for each egg. Eggs are one of the staples, having a multitude of uses as bread ingredients, viands paired with rice, or as bread fillings.

To help him continue his business, he is requesting a loan of 18000 PHP. He will be using the loan to buy more quantities of eggs to be sold and to replenish stocks for his variety store. He expects a boost in his business income as he expands his businesses.
  
Abraham hopes that all of his work will enable him to renovate his house soon. He faithfully meets with his co-fellowship* members to share stories of his work every week.

* All CCT community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet weekly. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay microfinance loans.

loans.use: To buy assorted grocery stock and eggs to be sold

loans.name: Simion Komen

texts.en:
Simion Komen C. has been selling cereals in Naivasha town for the last four years. He is 38 years old and married to Agnes Jerop. They have six children.

Simion was introduced to KADET Ltd. by a friend, and this will be his second loan. He paid his first loan well and in good time. He plans to use this loan to buy maize and beans in bulk for sale.

In the future, Simion also wants to venture into real estate and develop his rental houses.

loans.use: To buy maize and beans in bulk for resale

loans.name: Veronica

texts.en:
This is Veronica T., 37, a resident of Dasmariñas, Cavite City, Philippines. She is married to Rodante T. and has three children, one already in college, while the others attend high school. By the grace of God, Veronica has managed to support her children's schooling and is now working hard to be able to send them all the way through college, a dream of most Filipino parents like Veronica; she herself has been a college undergraduate and believes that a college diploma is the best legacy parents can leave to their children.

Veronica maintains a peanut butter business in which she prepares and processes raw peanuts into peanut butter, her regular customers being a school canteen and local offices. Veronica also operates an e-loading business whereby she purchases electronic cellular phone loads in large amounts and then retails them, her profit dependent upon the network's policy of dealership. For example, she may buy Php3000 worth of loads for Php2500, yielding a Php500 profit, depending on promos and quotas set by the networks.

To help her continue operation of her businesses, Veronica is requesting a Php45,000 loan to buy orders of peanut butter for her customers and electronic cellular phone loads from various network providers. She expects a boost in her business income as she expands her operation.

Veronica dreams of being able to give all of her children a good and high quality education through her hard work. To that end, she faithfully meets with her co-fellowship* members to share stories of her work every week.

* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. Each fellowship group, composed of 15 to 30 community partners, gathers every week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay Micro Finance loans.

loans.use: To buy orders of peanut butter for her customers and electronic cellular phone load from various network providers

loans.name: Betty

texts.en: Betty A.  is currently in the business of selling a variety goods such as beans, onions etc and is requesting a loan to stock more items to sell.  Betty is 28 years old and is married. Her husband is a business man. She has 3 children and 1child goes to school.  With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to open up a shop.

loans.use: stock more  items to sell

loans.name: Zephania

texts.en:
Zephania, 22 years old, has been farming in Naivasha town since 2000.  He sells his products in the local market and also to middle men who take them to the capital city Nairobi, where they sell for a profit.

He was introduced to KADET LTD by his friend and this will be his first loan.  He plans to use the cash to buy fertilizer and pesticides for his crop in the field.

Zephania hopes to own his own farming equipment in future. This will save him the cash he uses to rent the equipment when planting and harvesting.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer and pesticides for his crops.

loans.name: Fe

texts.en:
This is Fe B., 46, resident of Dasmariñas, Cavite City, Philippines. She is married to Erlito Jose B. and mother to four young hard working adults. One is working and helping out with the household finances, while the others are still in college. By the grace of God, Fe has managed to support her children's schooling up to college level. At this time, she is working hard to continually provide income for their every day expenses.

Fe operates a variety store where, during the evenings, she also sells bar-b-qued food. She also does direct selling of frozen cuts of meat and native meat delicacies. In the Philippines, a variety store is basically a small convenience store, which retails groceries, toiletries and beverages piecemeal to the local neighborhood. It is the place to go for to buy one sachet of shampoo, a Php5-worth of cooking oil, or an egg. She earns by getting supplies in wholesale price and selling in piece rate.  Her store is located adjacent to her house. Her regular customers are her neighbors and the local community.  She earns a minimum of Php300 in sales every day.

To help her continue operations of her business, she is requesting a Php11, 000 loan. She will be utilizing the loan to buy more quantities of products like groceries, toiletries and beverages to expand her product inventory. She will also invest a portion of her loan to buy meat, spices, sauce and firewood for her barbecues. She expects a boost in her business income as she expands her business. 
 
Fe dreams of being able to renovate her house soon, with all of her work with the business. She faithfully meets up with her co-fellowship* members to share stories of her work every week.

* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay Micro Finance loans.

loans.use: To buy products like groceries, toiletries and beverages to expand her product inventory and meat, spices, sauce and firewood for her barbecues

loans.name: Rose

texts.en: Rose T. is currently in the business of selling a variety of goods such as bread, charcoal etc and is requesting a loan to stock more bags of charcoal to sell.  Rose is 36 years old and is married with a husband that is works for NTC . She has 5 children and 3 of her children go to school.  With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to buy goats and rare them at home.

loans.use: Stock more bags of charcoal to sell

loans.name: Taciana

texts.en:
This is Taciana B., 52, resident of Dasmariñas, Cavite, Philippines. She is married to Virgilio B., an overseas Filipino worker, and mother of two young hard working adults.

Taciana operates a rug-making business while raising a few hogs. She mainly offers rugs, from those round palm sized ones, to the much larger doormats, braided quilts and bed sheets, and other crafts that most rug-makers supply. As rugs are a major part of Filipino housekeeping and cleaning, rugs are one of the most common products that can be bought, sometimes even from a peddler while you are riding in a speeding jeepney down the highway. Her regular customers are her neighbors and the local community.  She earns a minimum of Php350 in sales every day.

To help her continue operations of her business, she is requesting a Php14, 000 loan. She will be using the loan to buy more quantities of raw materials like fabric, thread and newspapers for patterns. She expects a boost in her business income as she expands her business.
  
Taciana dreams that her business will be successful. She faithfully meets up with her co-fellowship* members to share stories of her work every week.

* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay Micro Finance loans.

loans.use: buy more quantities of raw materials like fabric, thread and newspapers for patterns

loans.name: Salvacion

texts.en:
This is Salvacion G., 37, resident of Dasmariñas, Cavite City, Philippines. She is married to Romeo G., a tricycle driver, and mother to three young hard working teenagers. By the grace of God, Salvacion has managed to support her children's schooling. At this time, she is working hard to continually provide income for their every day expenses.

Salvacion operates a variety store where she also sells mineral water. In the Philippines, a variety store is basically a small convenience store, which retails groceries, toiletries and beverages, piecemeal, to the local neighborhood. It is the place to go for to buy one sachet of shampoo, a PHP5 worth of cooking oil, or an egg. She earns by getting supplies in wholesale price and selling at a piece rate. Her store is located adjacent to her house. Her regular customers are her neighbors and the local community. She earns a minimum of PHP300 in sales every day.

To help her continue operations of her business, she is requesting a PHP18, 000 loan. She will be utilizing the loan to buy more quantities of products like groceries, toiletries and beverages to expand her product inventory. She expects a boost in her business income as she expands her business.
  
Salvacion dreams to be able to renovate her house soon with all of her work with the business. She faithfully meets up with her co-fellowship* members to share stories of her work every week.

* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay Micro Finance loans.

loans.use: To buy more quantities of products like groceries, toiletries and beverages to expand her product inventory.

loans.name: Hellen

texts.en: Hellen P. is currently in the business of selling mixed goods like maize flour, beans etc. She is requesting a loan to stock more current goods to sell.  Hellen is 30 years old and is married. Her husband is a driver. She has 3 children and 2 of her children go to school. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to open up a shop.

loans.use: To stock more current goods to sell.

loans.name: Janet

texts.en: Janet S. is currently in the business of selling mixed goods such as bread, tomatoes, etc. She is requesting a loan to stock more of these current goods to sell. Janet is 32 years old and is married. Her husband is a businessman. She has 2 children and her children go to school. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to open up a drugstore.

loans.use: To stock more current goods to sell.

loans.name: Nenita

texts.en:
This is Nenita L., 57, resident of Dasmariñas, Cavite City, Philippines. She is mother to two young hard-working adults who are currently enrolled in high school. By the grace of God, Nenita has managed to support her children's schooling. At this time, she is working hard to continually send both of her children all the way through college.

Nenita operates a variety store. In the Philippines, a variety store is basically a small convenience store, which retails groceries, toiletries and beverages piecemeal to the local neighborhood. It is the place to go for to buy one sachet of shampoo, a PHP5 worth of cooking oil, or an egg. She earns by getting supplies at a wholesale price and selling by piece rate. Her store is located adjacent to her house. Her regular customers are her neighbors and the local community.  She earns a minimum of PHP300 in sales every day.

To help her continue operations of her business, she is requesting a PHP19,000 loan. She will be utilizing the loan to buy more quantities of products like groceries, toiletries and beverages to expand her product inventory. She expects a boost in her business income as she expands her business.
  
Nenita dreams to be able to renovate her house soon, with all of the work with her business. She faithfully meets up with her co-fellowship* members to share stories of her work every week.

* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay Micro Finance loans.

loans.use: To buy more quantities of products such as groceries, toiletries and beverages, to expand her product inventory

loans.name: Joyce

texts.en: Joyce P.  is currently in the business of selling cooked rice, beans, tea, etc. at her restaurant and she is requesting a loan to stock more food supplies to cook and sell from her restaurant. Joyce is 47 years old and is married. Her husband is a farmer. She has 6 children and 3 of her children go to school.  With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to expand the floor of her restaurant.

loans.use: To stock more foodstuffs to cook and sell from her restaurant.

loans.name: Nancy Jemuge

texts.en:
Nancy J. C. is 50 years of age, married to Elisha Rotich and the mother of five children: Faith, Jerono, Kiplagat, Jematur and Jepchirchir. Nancy supports her family and her husband subsidizes her income. Nancy runs a clothing business in Kabarnet town, which she started 15 years ago.

From this business, she makes a monthly profit of 30,000 Kenyan shillings (KES). She is applying for her third loan of 64,500 KES. She intends to use 40,000 KES to purchase skirts, 10,000 KES to purchase ladies handbags and the remaining 14,500 KES will be used to buy ladies shoes. Nancy intends to plough back her profits into the business for more growth. She has been able to service the loan successfully. Nancy hopes and dreams to see all her children through university and later to buy a family car.

loans.use: To purchase more skirts, ladies handbags and shoes for ladies

loans.name: Simon

texts.en: Simon is 34 years old and a member of the Jiinuwe Ngando group under Faulu Kenya.  He runs a retail shop and video cinema.  He also has a part-time job where he earns more income.  He has been running his business for three years with two employees.  Simon is a visionary and hardworking man who hopes to expand his shop into a wholesale business. With the loan of 20,000 Kes, he will buy sodas, confectionery, and movies.

loans.use: To buy sodas, confectionery, and movies

loans.name: Selina

texts.en: Selina P. makes a living selling rice, seeds and other items, and is applying for this loan to buy bags of rice from Uganda to sell to her customers.  She is 33 years old, married to a driver, and has eight children, four of whom are currently in school. She plans to use the profits generated by this loan to pay her children's school fees.

loans.use: To buy bags of rice to sell to her customers

loans.name: Umary Isa

texts.en:
B. Isa Umary is 28 years old and lives in the town of Kijura in the Hoima region of Uganda.  He is married and has one child who is not yet old enough to attend school. For the last two years, he has made a living by selling phone accessories.        

To help expand his business, Umary has requested a loan of 2000,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda. He will use the loan to buy more accessories to sell to his customers. He plans to use the income made possible by this loan to support his family, mostly by buying food. In the future, he hopes to open additional stores where he can sell his wares.

loans.use: to buy more phone accessories to sell to his customers

loans.name: Agnes

texts.en: Agnes K. makes a living by selling rice, beans, and other items and has applied for this loan to buy more bags of rice and beans from Uganda to sell to her customers. Agnes is 49 years old, married to a driver, and has six children, three of whom are enrolled in school. With the extra income made possible by this loan, she hopes to expand her business.

loans.use: To buy more bags of rice and beans from Uganda to sell

loans.name: Margret

texts.en:
Margret B. is 32 years old and lives in the town of Kijura in the Hoima region of Uganda. She is married and has two children, one of whom is currently in school. For the last two years, she has made a living by running a beauty salon.          

To help expand her business, Margret has requested a loan of 1,500,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda. She will use this loan to buy more of the supplies she needs to run her shop. Her goal is to increase her profits and buy more food for her family. In the future, Margret hopes to open other branches of her beauty salon.

loans.use: to buy more supplies for her beauty salon

loans.name: Rashid

texts.en:
Rashid B. is 43 years old and lives in the town of Masidi in the Hoima region of Uganda. He is divorced and has seven children, six of whom are currently in school. He makes a living by selling products made of clay, and has been in this line of work for more than 10 years. He also owns houses which he rents out.  

To help expand his business, Rashid has applied for a loan of 1,500,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda. He will use this loan to expand his business, increase his profits and buy more food for his family. In the future, he hopes to earn enough money to be financially independent.

loans.use: to expand his business

loans.name: Fredrick

texts.en:
Fredrick T. is 29 years old and lives in the town of Masindi in the Hoima region of Uganda. He is married and has one child, who is not in school. Fred runs a lodge, which he has had for over 10 years. He also has a retail shop.

To help expand his business, Fredick has requested a loan of 2,000,000 Ugandan shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to purchase items that were not there in the lodge, like more bed sheets and beds. With the help of this loan from BRAC, Fredick hopes to generate greater profits and buy food. In the future, Fred hopes to turn the lodge into a modern hotel with better facilities.

loans.use: To buy bed sheets and beds for a lodge

loans.name: Pirisila

texts.en: Pirisila A. is currently in the business of selling charcoal, sugar, tomatoes, etc.,  and is requesting a loan to improve on her stock. She is 50 years old and widowed. She has five children who all go to school. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to open up a big shop.

loans.use: To increase her stock

loans.name: Fredrick

texts.en:
Fredrick K. K. is 46 years old and lives in the town of Masidi in the Hoima region of Uganda. He is married and has 8 children. Five of his children are currently in school. Fredrick has a business of a retail shop, which he has had for 7 years. He owns rental houses as well.

To help expand his business, Fredrick has requested a loan of 1,500,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to purchase and stock more items like soap and sugar. With the help of the loan from BRAC, Fredrick hopes to generate greater profits and pay school fees. In the future, Fredrick hopes to expand his business.

loans.use: To buy and stock more items like soap and sugar.

loans.name: Mary

texts.en:
Mary K. M. is 42 years old and lives in the town of Masindi in the Hoima region of Uganda. She is divorced and has 3 children. All of her children are currently in school. Mary has a business of selling household items, which she has had for over 10 years. She owns a 30 acre sugar cane plantation.  

To help expand her business, Mary has requested a loan of 1,500,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to purchase bigger saucepans. With the help of the loan from BRAC, Mary hopes to generate greater profits and pay school fees. In the future, Mary hopes to own a bigger supermarket.

loans.use: To buy bigger saucepans.

loans.name: Jerisa

texts.en: Jerisa Y. is currently in the business of selling rice and sugar, and owns a bar. She is requesting a loan to improve her stock. Jerisa is 45 years old and is widowed. She has 4 children and only 1 of her children goes to school. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to buy goats and other goods for business.

loans.use: Improve her stock.

loans.name: Tereza

texts.en: Tereza A. is currently in the business of selling coffee and fish, and has a little bar. She is requesting a loan to improve on her small business buy stocking more fish to sell. Tereza is 45 years old and is Divorced.   She has 3 children and 2 of her children attend school.  With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to invest and continue with her business

loans.use: Improve her small business by stocking more fish to sell.

loans.name: Charity

texts.en: Charity P. is currently in the business of selling medicine at a shop and is requesting a loan to improve her stock of medicines. Charity is 23 years old and is married to a farmer. She has no children. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to expand her pharmacy.

loans.use: Improve her stock.

loans.name: Nathan

texts.en:
Nathan Asimwe is 51 years old and lives in the town of Masindi in the Hoima region of Uganda. He is married and has 7 children. Three of his children are currently in school. Nathan has a business of a retail shop, which he has had for over 10 years. He has rental houses as well.

To help expand his business, Nathan has requested a loan of 2000,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to purchase more items like sugar. With the help of the loan from BRAC, Nathan hopes to generate greater profits and pay school fees. In the future, Nathan hopes to own a bigger wholesale shop.

loans.use: To buy more items like sugar.

loans.name: Aida

texts.en:
This is Aida A., 38, resident of Pasay City, Philippines. She is married to Gregorio A., a driver/mechanic, and mother to four children, three of whom are in high school while the youngest is currently in elementary. By the grace of God, Aida has managed to support her children's schooling. At this time, she is working hard to continually send all of them all the way through college.

Aida oversees operations of their jeepney (see footnote) and tricycle transportation business. They have long (20-22 person capacity) and short (14-16 person capacity) jeepneys, all of which pay boundary (daily quota) each day. Aida’s husband also drives one of the jeepneys.
 
To help her continue operation of her business, she is requesting a Php10,000 loan. She will be utilizing the loan to buy spare parts and repair the tricycle and jeepney. She expects a boost in her business income as she expands her business.
  
Aida dreams of being able to buy another jeepney soon. She also dreams that her children will finish their education. She faithfully meets up with her co-fellowship* members to share stories of her work every week.

- Jeepneys have purely American origins. They were first used by American soldiers helping the Philippines throw off the invading Japanese. Filipino ingenuity, however, managed to see this vehicle as an opportunity to earn, and modified the Jeep into a 20-seater jeepney, open enough to provide adequate ventilation, sturdy for every day travel, and cheap enough to buy and maintain. Now, the jeepneys are one of the things that makes the Philippines truly Philippines.

* All CCT community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay Micro Finance loans.

loans.use: To buy spare parts and repair tricycle and jeepney.

loans.name: Daniel Michael's Group

texts.en:
Salone Microfinance Trust (SMT), a Kiva partner in Makeni, Northern Sierra Leone, is pleased to present to you the teachers of the WCSL Primary School, Kalangba village, near Makeni. WCSL Primary School was founded in 1942 by the Weslyan Mission to help educate the children of Kalangba Chiefdom. Currently, the school is staffed with 21 teachers and 422 pupils. This school is proud of the many doctors, teachers and other professionals that have passed through it.

This is the first loan that this school has applied for from SMT/Kiva lenders. Daniel M. M. is their leader and headmaster at the school. Daniel, age 53, was born in Kalangba village and has been in the teaching profession for 35 years now. He is married and has nine children: four in secondary school, three in college and the rest are now grown-ups and living on their own accord. 

School staff from this institution, like many other schools' staff within SMT’s operational areas, come to SMT to apply for loans. With the help of these loans, they can accomplish certain tasks that they would otherwise not have been able to accomplish with their mere salaries alone. With the help of this loan, some can pay school fees for their children; others can use the loan to buy pieces of furniture, a plot of land, house-building materials or invest in business. At the end of each month, these teachers repay their loan out of their monthly salaries. The institution’s bursar is directly responsible for deducting the repayment and pays SMT on their behalf.

Mr. M., leader of this group, has requested this loan in order to pay for the school charges of his children.

Included in this photo is loan officer Mary Y. Conteh, in green, hugging Daniel M. M..

loans.use: To pay school charges for his children

loans.name: Sarah

texts.en:
Sarah K. is 37 years old and lives in the town of Kinobi in the Hoima region of Uganda. She is married and has 4 children. All of her children are currently in school. Sarah has a business of a retail shop, which she has had for 1 year. She also has a produce business.

To help expand her business, Sarah has requested a loan of 1,500,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to purchase more produce and items for the retail shop, like soap. With the help of the loan from BRAC, Sarah hopes to generate greater profits and buy food. In the future, Sarah hopes to become a sufficient woman with a progressive business.

loans.use: To buy more produce and items for the retail shop, like soap.

loans.name: Faisal

texts.en:
Faisal S. is 27 years old and lives in the town of Kinubi in the Hoima region of Uganda. He is married and has 2 children. All of his children are currently in school. Faisal has a business of a garment shop, which he has had for 3 years.         

To help expand his business, Faisal has requested a loan of 1,500,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to purchase more items like clothes and perfumes. With the help of the loan from BRAC, Faisal hopes to generate greater profits and pay for school fees and food. In the future, Faisal hopes to build a successful business.

loans.use: To buy more items like clothes, perfumes.

loans.name: Beatrice

texts.en:
Beatrice S. is 37 years old and lives in the town of Kinubi in the Hoima region of Uganda. She is single and has 2 children. All of her children are currently in school. Beatrice has a business of a garment shop, which she has had for 3 years.         

To help expand her business, Beatrice has requested a loan of 1,500,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to purchase more items and stock, like clothes. With the help of the loan from BRAC, Beatrice hopes to generate greater profits and pay school fees. In the future, Beatrice hopes to build up a progressive business.

loans.use: To buy more items and stock, like clothes.

loans.name: Roselyne

texts.en:
Roselyne B. is 38 years old and lives in the town of Kinubi in the Hoima region of Uganda. She is married and has 3 children. All of her children are currently in school. Roselyne has a business of a garment shop, which she has had for 8 years.         

To help expand her business, Roselyne has requested a loan of 1,500,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to purchase more clothes and suitcases. With the help of the loan from BRAC, Roselyne hopes to generate greater profits and buy food. In the future, Roselyne hopes to set up another business.

loans.use: To purchase more clothes and suitcases.

loans.name: Adilbek

texts.en:
Adilbek K. is the young father of two beautiful daughters: five and three years old. He aims for a prosperous future for them, and does his best to achieve this goal. After graduating from Agricultural college, for four years, he has sold jeans at the market in the capital city Bishkek, where he met Sablat, his wife. They decided to move to Tokmok city, near the capital, and settle there. This couple went through hard times, with the lack of a home and money, but didn’t give up.

Sablat, in order to support her family, began to sew Kyrgyz national traditional clothes – “chapan” and “chepken” and embroider them with ornamental patterns. This activity started to bring permanent profit and customers increased. It led Adilbek to master the profession of seamstress - he bought one more sewing machine and helped his wife in this business. They worked hard and managed to enlarge it through raising floating capital, purchasing additional equipment, and hiring workers. With the revenues from these activities, Adilbek bought a small flat for his family and a used car.

Now Adilbek wants to take a loan of 70,000 KGS to purchase fabrics and thread and expand the range of products in his shop. He hopes that this will help him to increase revenues. In the future, Adilbek dreams of buying a big house for his family and to see more children in it.  

Bai-Tushum and Partners uses Kiva funding to target the especially vulnerable population. Bai-Tushum and Partners is one of the leading Microfinance Institutions in Kyrgyzstan. As a reliable financial partner, Bai-Tushum contributes to the economic development of the Kyrgyz Republic through the delivery of microfinance services in rural and urban areas that lead to increased employment and meet the interests of its clients and investors.

loans.use: To purchase fabrics and thread.

loans.name: Shahodat

texts.en:
Shahodat is a brave married woman who works hard for the good of her three children, and she does so alone. The strict discipline she uses with her children allows her to count on her household’s advice and support in working the fields. Shahodat’s children’s grateful attitude continues to encourage her and they have gathered many lessons during this time that they can use when they form their own households. What Shahodat urgently needs right now are fertilizers and other chemicals for cultivating her land and to be prepared for upcoming growing season. Shahodat doesn’t just need good land; she also needs a friendly hand to help her out.

More about Tajikistan and IMON International:

Tajikistan is known for its rich history, which includes a key post along the Silk Road and the end of Alexander the Great's rule. It has also produced great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets, including Rudaki, Avicenna, Ferdowsi, Omar Khayyam, Jomi, and Rumi. The country is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, epic mountain passes, and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium BC. And, even today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture and Central Asian traditions.

But Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged the already weak economy. In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two thirds of the population still live in abject poverty.

IMON's History:

Since December 2007, IMON International has worked closely with Kiva and Kiva lenders to ensure that poor and low income clients represent a viable business proposition. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: To purchase seeds and mineral fertilizer.

loans.name: Gafurjon

texts.en:
Gafurjon owns a retail business located in Istaravshan city. He sells clothing for kids. Gafurjon has been in this business for 5 years. He knows his clients and their tastes well and chooses the right inventory, so his business does well. Gafurjon would like to get a loan of 7500 Somoni to purchase more autumn clothing to sell. Gafurjon’s goal is to improve his business conditions – to build a nice little store at the same place where his container is located now.

To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: To purchase new clothing in order to increase the range of goods for selling.

loans.name: Kosim

texts.en:
Kosim K. is 63 years old. He is married and has three children. He has been very familiar with agriculture since he was young. Thanks to his parents he knows how to work the land. Now Kosim supports himself entirely from vegetable production. He works all day cleaning, irrigating and fertilizing his fields so that his production will be good. He has always liked cleaning his fields because it is important and is lighter work than many of his tasks. Kosim wishes to improve his family's quality of life; that wish provides the motivation for his arduous work. Kosim will invest the loan in the purchase of seeds, fertilizer, fuels and lubricants, with the aim to have the best production in his community in a few months.

loans.name: Jahongir

texts.en:
Jahongir S. is 23 years old. He is a young married man and has one child. Jahongir has a butcher shop and has run a meat selling business for 12 years. He provides the markets with meat and his family with the necessary food. Now, Jahongir is requesting a loan of $1500 USD. Due to the profitability of his business, the determination of this micro entrepreneur, and his experience in the business, this customer is qualified to receive this loan. It is the high season for sales now, and Jahongir wants to take advantage of it to increase his profits.  
 
More about Tajikistan and IMON International:
