loans.use: to purchase additional seeds, seedlings & young crops to raise

loans.name: Bat-Erdene

texts.en: Bat-Erdene B. is 46 years old and lives with his wife and two daughters in Arhangai province of Mongolia. He and his family live in a ger, a traditional Mongolian nomadic tent. His oldest daughter, 20, is a university student while his youngest son, 15, attends a local high school. His wife sells farm supplies for livestock in the central city of province. Bat-Erdene operates a timber trading business in his town. He started his business in 2004 with 1,500,000 MNT of working capital which was used to purchase a vehicle. Over years of operation, he has built a stable and successful operation and his working capital has grown to 4,000,000 MNT. He purchases his timber from Bulgan province and sells it back to the local town for profit. He has gained much experience and also has a wide range of customer both in Arhangai and Bayanhongor provinces. He is a modest and hardworking man. He is requesting a 3,000,000 MNT loan to buy more timber and logs in order to increase his sales.

loans.use: To buy more timber and logs

loans.name: Robert Gikaba

texts.en:
Robert has been running his retail shop in Naivasha town for the last three years.  He is 38 years old, married to Tabitha Njoki and they have one child.  

He was introduced to KADET LTD by his friend and this will be his second loan.  He paid his previous loan of Kshs 30,000 well and in good time.  He plans to use the loan amount to buy a second hand motorbike which he will employ somebody else to operate for him in motorcycle transport business.  This will increase his daily income. He is very determine and hardworking.

loans.use: To buy a second hand motorbike.

loans.name: Livingstone Odhiambo

texts.en:
Livingstone has operated his welding shop in Naivasha town for the last eight years.  He is 37 years old, married to Rose Akinyi and they have thee children.

He was introduced to KADET LTD by his friend and this will be his third loan.  He paid his previous loans well and in good time.  He plans to use the loan amount to buy raw materials for the welding work.

In future, Livingstone hopes to grow his business and be able to employ people to work for him.

loans.use: To buy raw materials for welding work .

loans.name: Pagamjav

texts.en:
Pagamjav V. is 39 years old and lives with her husband and five children in Harhorin, the ancient capital city of Mongolian Empire, in Uvurhangai province in central Mongolia. She and her family live together in a ger, a traditional Mongolian nomadic housing tent. Her oldest daughter attends university and her two daughters and two sons all attend a local school. Her husband operates a ger's wood making business and also he drives a taxi between neighboring sub provinces to supplement his family's income. 

Pagamjav and her husband have been producing framing for ger's, according to customers' orders, since 1991 and they started to operate a used clothing trading business in their town as well. Over the years, the couple has gained much experience and have built a stable operation. Moreover, they made a motorized land drilling machine and rents it to people daily at 50,000 MNT. 

For the future, Pagamjav hopes to grow her businesses further and says, "We are working hard to provide for our children's education." She is requesting a 1,700,000 MNT loan to purchase winter clothes for her second hand clothing sales business as well as to make some exterior construction on her house.

loans.use: To purchase winter clothes

loans.name: Amangeldi

texts.en:
Amangeldi A. is a 69 years-old farmer. He has had a happy marriage with his wife, Taalaybubu for 50 years and has ten grown children. All Amangeldi’s life was closely connected with agriculture - he worked as a tractor driver for a long time. Now he and his wife are on pension and have a farm with three milk cows, whose daily milk yield of 20 liters is sold at the local market. Also, this couple is engaged in cultivating wheat, beets and clover and work hard to get a good harvest. These activities allow them to make some savings for their old age and support their grandchildren. 

Amangeldi plans to use the loan of 60,000 KGS to expand his farm by buying two milk cows, which will allow increased milk sales, and also buy forage for the cattle. With the revenues from the loan, he plans to broaden his business by purchasing more cattle.

Amangeldi is a very attentive grandfather who loves children’s voices ringing in his house and does all his best to provide their prosperous future. 

Bai-Tushum and Partners uses Kiva funding to target the especially vulnerable population. Bai-Tushum and Partners is one of the leading Microfinance Institutions in Kyrgyzstan. As a reliable financial partner, Bai-Tushum contributes to the economic development of the Kyrgyz Republic through the delivery of microfinance services in rural and urban areas that lead to increased employment and meet the interests of its clients and investors.

loans.use: to purchase cattle

loans.name: Paul Njamba

texts.en:
Paul has operated his workshop in Naivasha town for the last 11 years.  He is 41 years old, married to Mirriam Mweru and they have  children who are all going to school.

He was introduced to KADET  LTD by his friend and this will be his second  loan.  He paid his previous loan of Kshs 25,000 well and in good time.  He plans to use the loan amount to  buy a multi purpose wood work machine.

In the future, Paul plans to open a show room where he will be displaying the furniture he has made. He is hardworking and wants his children to have a better education.

loans.use: To buy a multi purpose wood work machine.

loans.name: George Njoroge

texts.en:
George has operated in the taxi transport industry for five years.  He has mainly operated in Naivasha town.  He is 26 years old and recently got married to Diana Wanjiru.

He was introduced to KADET LTD  by a friend and this will be his third loan.  He paid his previous loans well and in good time.  He plans to use the cash from this loan to have his taxi for serviced and body repaired.  He also hopes to own a mini bus in future which he will use for transportation.

loans.use: To have his taxi for serviced and the body repaied.

loans.name: Gaamaa

texts.en:
Gaamaa D. is 51 years old and lives with her husband and two children in Ulaanbaatar, the capital city of Mongolia. She and her family live in their own ger, a traditional Mongolian nomadic home tent. Her son works as a salesperson in the KJK company while her daughter is a teacher at the Kanan Co.ltd. Her husband is retired and currently helps out with the business. 

Gaamaa has been operating clothes selling business since 2009 in the rented outdoor space at the Urt Tsagaan trade center in Ulaanbaatar. Over the many years of operation, she has gained a lot of experience as a businesswoman and her daily revenue reaches between 90,000 and 100,000 MNT. She pays rent fees of 100,000 MNT per month. She has had 13 loans and fully paid off all her loans on time. Gaamaa is a very modest and happy woman and says, " We have been living for many years in the ger and now I want to purchase an apartment where can live in the civilized environment with my family." She is requesting a 2,000,000 MNT loan to import products such as children's clothes and slippers etc, from China to sell.

loans.use: To import more products

loans.name: Makhoul

texts.en: Makhoul is a 47 years old married man, father of four children, living in Bint Jbeil with his beloved family. Makhoul owns a generator, through which he provides electricity to multiple houses in his village and in the neighborhood.  Since 1990 he has also been doing construction work since he’s an electrician . Makhoul is requesting a loan from Al Majmoua for the second time, in order to pay for his kids’ school fees and supplies. The previous loan was for his business, through which he bought the generator he is working on now, and was very effective.  He hopes to expand his business and relax in the future.

loans.use: To pay for his kids' school fees

loans.name: God Is Good To Us Group

texts.en:
Mariyah S., who is holding the sign, is the leader of this group of five borrowers called God Is Good To Us. She is 28 years old and single with two children, aged 5 and 7. She was only able to attend school through 10th grade due to lack of financial support. She cares for one sibling.

For five years, she has been selling door locks and shoe polish in West Point Monrovia, Liberia. She plans to use her 6,000 Liberian Dollars (LRD) of this 30,000 LRD group loan to buy more door locks and shoe polish. She describes herself as a God-fearing woman whose dream is to improve her business and build a house.

In the photo that accompanies this profile, Helena is inset at the lower right because she was absent during disbursement.

loans.use: To buy more door locks and shoe polish for resale

loans.name: Susanna

texts.en: Susanna G. is married with three daughters. Susanna’s husband, unable to find a job in his home country, left for Russia. Since 2006, Susanna has been trading in clothing. One of her daughters helps her hardworking mother in running the business. Susanna has applied for this loan to purchase new clothing stock.

loans.use: To purchase new clothing stock

loans.name: Mickmass

texts.en:
Mickmass O. is 27 years old and lives in the town of Nebbi in the West Nile region of Uganda. He is single and has no children. Mickmass has a business selling second-hand clothes which he has operated for six years.         

To help expand his business, Mickmass has requested a loan of 1,500,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to purchase more stock. With the help of the loan from BRAC, Mickmass hopes to generate greater profits and to take care of himself. In the future, Mickmass hopes to open other branches in different districts.

loans.use: To purchase more stock.

loans.name: Try Us Group

texts.en:
Pictured here are members of the “Try Us” group. They are small-scale businesspeople from the township of Magburaka, in northern Sierra Leone. They are seeking a loan of SLL 500,000 for each to enable them to further expand their businesses. Consequently, they will make more profit and improve their living conditions. 

The leader of this group is Sulaiman K.. Sulaiman is aged fifty-two and was born in Magburaka town. He is married with ten children. His wife is a businesswoman and seven of his children are attending primary school.  For twelve years now, Sulaiman has been selling shoes, clothes, vests, rice and palm oil. With this loan, he will expand his business by buying the above-mentioned items in large quantity. 

(Attached to this photo is a snapshot of a borrower who was not able to be present for the group photo.)

loans.use: Buy shoes, clothes, vests, rice and palm oil

loans.name: Kurbon

texts.en:
Kurbon is 27 years old and married with two children. Kurbon sells children's clothing and footwear. He has been in this business for three years. Kurbon attracts customers with good client service and affordable prices and has many repeat clients. Kurbon would like to borrow $2300 USD to increase his assortment. His business goal is to start a second location to make more money for his family. This business is the only source of income for his family.
 
More about Tajikistan and IMON International: Tajikistan is known for its rich history, which includes a key post along the Silk Road and the end of Alexander the Great's rule. It has also produced great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets, including Rudaki, Avicenna, Ferdowsi, Omar Khayyam, Jomi, and Rumi. The country is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, epic mountain passes and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium BC. Even today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture and Central Asian traditions.

But Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged the already weak economy. In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty.

IMON's History: Since December 2007, IMON International has worked closely with Kiva and Kiva lenders to ensure that poor and low income clients represent a viable business proposition. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit www.imon.tj.

loans.use: To purchase clothing for resale

loans.name: Zaitun

texts.en:
Zaitun A. is 38 years old and lives in the town of Arua Hill in the West Nile region of Uganda. She is married and has four children, three of which are in school. Zaitun has a hotel business which she has had for over 10 years.         

To help expand her business, Zaitun has requested a loan of 2,000,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to purchase more stock of food like rice and posho. With the help of the loan from BRAC, Zaitun hopes to generate greater profits, pay school fees and buy food. In the future, Zaitun hopes to open new branches of her business.

loans.use: To buy more stock of food like rice and posho

loans.name: Massiade Group

texts.en:
Sallay M. is the leader of this group of entrepreneurs. Sallay was born in Magburaka town, about thirty-five years ago. She is married to a policeman and the couple have three children – one in primary school and two in secondary school. 

For many years now, Sallay has been selling rice, tomatoes, onions, Maggi cubes (used to give sauce a sweet taste), etc. They are requesting a loan of SLL 500,000 for each. With the help of this loan, they will be able to expand their businesses, make more sales and consequently improve their living conditions. 

Sallay will use her share of the loan to expand her business; she will buy rice, tomatoes, onions, Maggi cubes etc. in large quantity to add to her business inventory.

loans.use: Buy rice, tomatoes, onions, Maggi cubes, etc. in large quantity

loans.name: Yasin

texts.en:
A. Yasin is 50 years old and lives in the town of Arua Hill in the West Nile region of Uganda.  He is married and has 6 children.  Four of his children are currently in school.  Yasin has a butcher shop, which he has had for over 10 years.         

To help expand his business, Yasin has requested a loan of 2,000,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda.  The loan will be used to purchase more  meat.  With the help of the loan from BRAC, Yasin hopes to generate greater profits and pay school fees.  In the future, Yasin hopes to own a firm.

loans.use: buying meat for resale

loans.name: Safia

texts.en:
Sophia A.  is 48 years old and lives in the town of Arua Hill in the west Nile region of Uganda.  She is married and has 6 children.  Four of her children are currently in school.  Sophia has a business of selling silver fish, which she has had for over 10 years.         

To help expand her business, Sophia has requested a loan of 2,000,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda.  The loan will be used to purchase and stock more of the silver fish.  With the help of the loan from BRAC, Sophia hopes to generate greater profits and pay school fees.  In the future, Sophia hopes to expand her business further.

loans.use: buying silver fish for resale

loans.name: Gabriel

texts.en:
Gabriel O. is 34 years old and married to Jacinta Anyango. They have seven children who are between 15 and six years old. They live in Corner legio in Kisumu city. 

Gabriel has a butcher shop and has been in this business for the last five years. He is applying for his second loan, after repaying his first loan without any difficulties. His monthly income is 10,000 Kenyan shillngs, and  he want to buy a bull to be used to add more meat to his shop. His clients mostly consist of hotel owners and the locals in his neighborhood. He intends to use the money to build a pig slaughter house that will enable him to sell pork in his shop.

His hope and dream is to see his business expand and give his children the best education.

loans.use: purchasing a bull for slaughter

loans.name: Mohira

texts.en:
A small entrepreneur from Khujand, Mohira sells fish in one of the community markets. She is married with one child. Mohira started her business 9 years ago. She launched her start-up and got straight to work making wholesale purchases and working long hours to sell the stock. Mohira's business can be characterized as growing and stable. Her rich experience working in this sphere has added a lot to this positive standing. 

We believe Mohira's decisiveness and ultimate focus on success will motivate her to repay the current loan of $2200 US on time. The loan will be very beneficial for the further expansion she has planned to implement, including opening a new vending stand.  
 
More about Tajikistan and IMON International

Tajikistan is known for its rich history, which includes a key post along the Silk Road and the end of Alexander the Great's rule. It has also produced great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets, including Rudaki, Avicenna, Ferdowsi, Omar Khayyam, Jomi, and Rumi. The country is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, epic mountain passes, and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium BC. And, even today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture and Central Asian traditions.

But Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged the already weak economy. In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty.

Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: Purchasing fish at wholesale

loans.name: Justo

texts.en:
G. Justo is 45 years old and lives in the town of Arua in the West Nile region of Uganda.  He is married and has 6 children.  Three of his children are currently in school.  Justo has a business selling hardware and doing welding, which he has had for over 10 years.         

To help expand his business, Justo has requested a loan of 1,500,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda.  The loan will be used to purchase more angle bars, square bars, and motor oil.  With the help of the loan from BRAC, Justo hopes to generate greater profits and pay school fees.  In the future, Justo hopes to expand his business.

loans.use: to buy more angle bars, square bars and motor oil

loans.name: Munavvar

texts.en:
Munavvar R., 44, is the loving mother of four children. For more than 17 years, Munavvar has sold fish in the central fish market of the city. When she started she had only 100 US dollars in turnover. With time, her business expanded and today it is quite stable. Munavvar requests 2200 US dollars. She wants to purchase fish at wholesale prices in order to have stock for selling during coming celebrations when fishing is prohibited. Munavvar has already been provided loans by IMON and has shown herself as a reliable client. She would like to thank everyone for supporting her.  

More about Tajikistan and IMON International:
Tajikistan is known for its rich history, which includes having been a key post along the Silk Road and having witnessed the end of Alexander the Great's rule. It has also produced great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets, including Rudaki, Avicenna, Ferdowsi, Omar Khayyam, Jomi, and Rumi. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit www.imon.tj

loans.use: To purchase wholesale fish for resale

loans.name: Bernard

texts.en:
Bernard O. is 28 years old and is married to Bebline, who is a housewife. They have three children, Melvin, 5, Naomi, 4, and Erick, who is one month old. They live in the Kikomi area in Kisumu city.

Bernard sells bicycle spare parts. He has been in this business for the past five years and earns a monthly income of 6000 KES. He is applying for his second loan after successfully completing the first one. He intends to use the money to buy more bicycle spare parts to add to his stock. Most of his customers are from his neighborhood and he has created a huge clientele.

His hopes and dreams are to expand his business and provide a good education for his children.

loans.use: To buy stocks of bicycle parts

loans.name: John Chege

texts.en:
John is 39 years old and married to Jane Wangui who is a secretary at the District Commissioner office. They have four children. John runs an electronics shop besides his taxi business, in Mwingi. He has been in the electronics business for a period of about 10 years with a monthly profit of approximately Kshs. 25,000.  

He intends to use the loan to buy solar panels for resale and with the extra profit buy a generator for power back up for his business. He hopes to put up some rental houses in the future and have a big stock of fridges and televisions.

loans.use: To buy solar panels for resale

loans.name: Tamemkoh Group

texts.en:
These are members of the “Tamemkoh II” group. They are small-scale businesswomen in the northern township of Magburaka. This will be their first loan from SMT/Kiva lenders.  With the help of this loan, these entrepreneurs will be able to expand their businesses, make more sales and better profit. 

Fatmata K. is the leader of this group. Fatmata was born in Magburaka town. She is thirty-five-years of age, married to a businessman and they have two children who are attending secondary schools. Fatmata has had many years of experience in business. She sells plastic bowls and baskets. She will use her share of this loan to expand her business by buying more plastic bowls and baskets to sell.

loans.use: to expand her business by buying more plastic bowls and baskets to sell

loans.name: Muhammad

texts.en:
Muhammad M. is married with two children. He lives in Khujand, in the northern part of Tajikistan, where he runs a grocery kiosk in the local market, selling oil, sugar, meat, and other products. In business for 15 years, he can boast competitive prices that help him find and keep his loyal clientele. Muhammad is seeking a loan of 1400 USD to increase his turnover capital. He has a family to provide for and works hard to meet all of their needs, including saving for his children’s schooling. 

More about Tajikistan and IMON International:
Tajikistan is known for its rich history, which includes having been a key post along the Silk Road and having witnessed the end of Alexander the Great's rule. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit www.imon.tj

loans.use: To increase working capital

loans.name: Madira

texts.en:
Madira J. is 42 years old and lives in the town of Arua in the West Nile region of Uganda.  He is married and has four children.  Three of his children are currently in school.  Madira has a business in selling hardware and other accessories  He has had this business for over 10 years.         

To help expand his business, Madira has requested a loan of 1,500,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda.  The loan will be used to purchase more items like radios, cables, and adapters.  With the help of the loan from BRAC, Madira hopes to generate greater profits and pay school fees.  In the future, Madira hopes to return this loan and get another loan.

loans.use: To buy more items like radios, cables, and adapters

loans.name: Kudrat

texts.en:
Kudrat A. is 24 years old and the father of two small children. Kudrat is a villager in Shahrituz, urban-type community in Southern Tajikistan. He and his wife are farmers who own 21 hectares of land to cultivate rice, wheat, onion and other vegetables. On their plantation, they now face an obstacle because they do not have enough money to buy seeds, fertilizer, fuels and lubricants for planting. So Kudrat decided to ask for a loan for this purpose. Kudrat has gained a reputation for his responsibility with financial obligations and for keeping his word.  We are happy to have another opportunity to assist him with the operation of his business. 

More about Tajikistan and IMON International

Tajikistan is known for its rich history, which includes a key post along the Silk Road and the end of Alexander the Great's rule. It has also produced great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets, including Rudaki, Avicenna, Ferdowsi, Omar Khayyam, Jomi, and Rumi. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: Purchasing seeds, fertilizer, fuels and lubricants

loans.name: Caro

texts.en:
Caro N. is 46 years old and lives in the town of Natete in the Kampala West region of Uganda.  She is married and has three children.  All of her children are currently in school.  Caro has a business in selling food which she has had for over 10 years.  She also owns rental houses and sells charcoal.

To help expand her business, Caro has requested a loan of 2,500,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda.  The loan will be used to purchase more charcoal and complete her rental houses.  With the help of the loan from BRAC, Caro hopes to generate greater profits and pay school fees.  In the future, Caro hopes to own anther plot of land and build more rental houses.

loans.use: To buy more charcoal and complete her  rental houses

loans.name: We Heart Dae Group

texts.en:
These are small-scale businesspeople in Magburaka, a town in northern Sierra Leone. They have come to SMT, a partner of Kiva.org, to seek a loan of SLL 800,000 for each to enable them to expand their businesses. With a loan of SLL 800,000, they will be able to add more stock to their businesses, make more sales, and more profit. Consequently, they will be able to improve their standard of living by sending their children to school, feeding and clothing them. 

Aye L. is the leader of this group. She was born in Mabonto village, near Magubraka town. She is fifty years old, married and has seven children. Her husband is a teacher and five of  her children are attending schools – one in college and four in primary school. 

Aye sells palm oil, rice, groundnuts, and peppers. She has been doing business for twenty-five years now. She will use her share of this loan to increase the size and quality of her business. She will buy the above-mentioned items in large quantity to add to her current stock.

loans.use: buy palm oil, rice, groundnuts, and peppers to increase the size of her business inventory

loans.name: Albert

texts.en:
Albert K. is a 46 year-old man.  He is married and is blessed with three kids. He supports a family of five people. Albert does horticultural farming as a source of his income in Tambach, Iten; he started his farming seven years ago.  From this business he gets a monthly income of Kshs 30,000. Albert has taken a third loan of Kshs 50,000 from KADET LTD.  He intends to use the loan as follows: Kshs 8,000 for seeds, Kshs 12,000 for fertilizers, Kshs 2,000 for fungicides, Kshs 2,500 for manure, Kshs. 5,000 for weeding, Kshs.10,000 for harvesting and the remaining amount for wages and other costs, i.e. transportation.

Albert intends to use the profits from the business to pay his children's school fees and use the rest to expand his business.  His dream is to build a storage house that he will be using to store and sell his farm produce.

loans.use: To purchase farm inputs like seeds, fertilizers, fungicides, manure and the rest of money for weeding, harvesting, etc.

loans.name: Aissatou

texts.fr: Madame Aissatou N. est une coiffeuse qui gére son salon de coiffure à Thiadiaye un arrondissement dans le département de Mbour .Elle vend également des produits cosmétiques et d'autres articles de beauté .Aissatou a sollicité ce prêt pour renforcer son commmerce pour l'acquisition de nouveaux produits déstinés à sa clientèle ainsi elle pourra  faire avancer son activité et faire face à ses besoins sociaux
texts.en: Mrs. Aissatou N. is a hair-dresser who runs a hair salon in Thiadiaye, a neighborhood within the Mbour district.  She sells both cosmetics and other beauty products.  Aissatou requested this loan in order to strengthen her business in order to acquire new products for her clientele. By doing so, she will be able to improve her business and be able to meet her basic needs.

loans.use: Commerce

loans.name: Joweria

texts.en:
Joweria A. is 34 years old and lives in the town of Natete in the Kampala West region of Uganda.  She is single and has three children.  All of her children are currently in school.  Joweria has a tailoring business, which she has had for five years.         

To help expand her business, Joweria has requested a loan of 2,000,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda.  The loan will be used to purchase more materials to make clothes.  With the help of the loan from BRAC, Joweria hopes to generate greater profits and pay school fees for her children.  In the future, Joweria hopes to build rental houses.

loans.use: To buy more materials to make clothes

loans.name: Robert

texts.en:
Robert S. is 22 years old and lives in the town of Natete in the Kampala west region of Uganda. He is married and has one child who is not currently in school. Robert has had a retail business for four years.         

To help expand his business, Robert has requested a loan of 1,500,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to purchase a computer and a printer for photographs. With the help of the loan from BRAC, Robert hopes to generate greater profits and buy food. In the future, Robert hopes to buy a film-editing machine.

loans.use: To buy  a computer and a printer for photographs

loans.name: Sophia

texts.en:
Sophia K. is 28 years old and lives in the town of Nateete in the Kampala West region of Uganda. She is married and has four children. All of her children are currently in school. Sophia has had a salon business for seven years.         

To help expand her business, Sophia has requested a loan of 1,500,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to purchase cosmetic lotions. With the help of the loan from BRAC, Sophia hopes to generate greater profits and take care of herself. In the future, Sophia hopes to expand her business and own a house.

loans.use: To buy more cosmetic lotions

loans.name: Ziyodullo

texts.en: Ziyodullo O. is 55 years old. He is married and has five children of school age. Ziyodullo is producing the national cradles. The national cradles in Tajikistan are very colorful. They are made of wood. As a rule, the national cradle is presented by the grandparents when the baby is 40 days old and this event is celebrated in the family circle. Ziyodullo has been in this business for 11 years. The finished products are purchased from the house of Ziyodullo. The business stability has allowed an income to ensure the family has the possibility to improve their living conditions. Ziyodullo has been working with IMON for two years. For the entire period of time, he had shown himself as a successful client, managing his loans with accuracy and precision. Today, Ziyodullo requests a loan in the amount of 6900 Somoni in order to purchase planks and paints for producing the cradles. More about Tajikistan and IMON International Tajikistan is known for its rich history, which includes being a key post along the Silk Road, and for the end of Alexander the Great's rule. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: Purchasing raw materials: planks and paints

loans.name: Ardan Duba

texts.en:
Ardan Duba is a 29-year-old businessman. He is married to Mary and  they have one child, aged 2. Ardan has been selling mobile accessories and doing mobile repairs for the past six years. His current monthly income is 26,000 Kenyan shillings, which he uses to support his family.

Ardan has never borrowed from another MFI (microfinance institution). He is applying for his first loan with KADET LTD. He was introduced to KADET LTD. through an existing client of KADET LTD.

The client plans to purchase a computer, printer and stationery with the loan. With the anticipated profits from his business, he intends to open another branch office in Nguni, Mwingi town. His hopes and dreams are to own a big business of computers, mobile accessories and mobile phones and also to construct a good permanent house for the family.

loans.use: Buy a computer, a printer and stationery to provide better cell-phone repair services

loans.name: Elmurzo

texts.en:
Elmurzo is a farmer devoted both to his work and to being the father of a family. He works hard in raising his cattle, taking them out to graze in the early mornings. Raising cattle is not an easy task, but his love for his family gives his work reason and meaning. Currently, Elmurzo wants to improve his situation by increasing his number of cattle which in the long run will provide better income.

More about Tajikistan and IMON International

Tajikistan is known for its rich history, which includes its role as a key post along the Silk Road and the end of Alexander the Great's rule. It has also produced great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets, including Rudaki, Avicenna, Ferdowsi, Omar Khayyam, Jomi, and Rumi. The country is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, epic mountain passes, and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium BC. And, even today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture and Central Asian traditions.

But Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged the already weak economy. In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty.

IMON's History

Since December 2007, IMON International has worked closely with Kiva and Kiva lenders to ensure that poor and low income clients represent a viable business proposition. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: Purchasing cattle to expand the business

loans.name: Apeiyo

texts.en:
Apeiyo A. is 56 years old and married. She and her spouse, who is unemployed, have eight children that they support. Apeiyo sells roasted maize and vegetables at Kabarnet municipal market. She has borrowed 10,000 KES as her second loan from KADET Ltd. She intends to use all of the money to purchase products to sell: 2,000 KES for green maize for roasting, 6,000 KES for potatoes, 1,000 KES for local vegetables, and 1,000 KES for ripe bananas.

Apeiyo plans to revinest the profits in her business. She hopes to get more capital so that she can eventually open a grocery store and a stall where she can sell clothes.

loans.use: To purchase maize and vegetables for resale

loans.name: Michael M.w.'s Group

texts.en:
Salone Microfinance Trust (SMT), a partner of Kiva.org in Makeni, northern Sierra Leone, is pleased to present to you teachers of the Feredugu R.C. Primary School. This school was founded on the 9th of September 1960 by the Catholic Mission to foster education in the Chiefdom. Currently, the school is staffed with eight teachers and has 400 pupils. 

This is the first loan that this school has applied for from SMT/Kiva lenders. Michael M.W. D. (who is sitting in front) is their leader and headmaster at the school. The fifty-eight-year-old Michael was born in Kambia, a town in northern Sierra Leone. He has been in the teaching profession for thirty-eight years now. He is married to a teacher and they have eight children - two are in secondary school and one is in college; the rest are now grown-ups and living on their own.

School staff from this institution, like many other schools' staff within SMT’s operational areas, come to SMT to apply for loans. With the help of these loans, they can accomplish certain tasks that they would otherwise not be able to accomplish with their mere salaries alone. But with the help of this loan, some can pay school fees for their children; others can use the loan to buy pieces of furniture, a plot of land, house-building materials, or invest in business. At the end of each month, these teachers can repay the loan out of their monthly salaries. The institution’s bursar is directly responsible for deducting the repayment and pays SMT on their behalf.

Mr. D., leader of this group, has requested this loan in order to construct a dwelling for his family. “This loan will ease some of my difficulties,” said Mr. D., “and will be a great development aid for my family,” he concluded.

loans.use: Buy house-building materials for the construction of a family home

loans.name: Madinahon's Group

texts.en:
Madinahon A. is the leader of the group. She is 19 and married. Her spouse is a cook. The couple has a son who is one year old. Together with her husband’s parents (her father-in-law works as a farmer, her mother-in-law is retired), she owns and operates a rest home. The profits from this business have enabled them to purchase a car and to make house repairs. The family hopes to get a loan in order to purchase hardware and iron for building a bridge. In the future Madinahon wants to expand the recreation area. 

Potmahon A., 51, is a widow. Her large family consists of the following members: her mother-in-law (retired), her son, her daughter, her daughter-in-law, and her grandchildren. All of the family members have different jobs. Her son works in Russia. Her daughter helps to run their farming business. By now they have harvested the onions. From the profits of the farm, they have been able to prepare a dowry, make house repairs, and arrange her son's wedding. The loan will be used to purchase onion seeds. In the future Potmahon will be spending money on her daughter’s wedding and her grandsons' circumcision ceremony, as well as adding a bathroom to her house. 

Muminahon A., 48, is married. She and her husband, who drives a private taxi, have raised two sons. Both of her sons work in construction. The family is building a shed and needs a loan in order to purchase cement and hardware. In the future Muminahon wants to finish improvements to her house, including kitchen and bathroom, and arrange her sons' weddings. 

Ozadahon T., 30, is married. Her spouse works in Russia. While he is gone, she is taking care of their four children by herself. The oldest child goes to the school; the youngest is just one year old. To earn an income, she sells fruits and vegetables. She began this business eight years ago by selling berries from her own garden. She is requesting a loan to purchase fruits and vegetables. In the future Ozadahon is planning to build a bathroom and a kitchen.

--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused microfinance institution in Kyrgyzstan. MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line – People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only microfinance institution in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about MBF and view a video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135 

If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loans.use: To purchase hardware and iron for bridge building

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: To buy more bags of charcoal

loans.name: Guluisun's Group

texts.en: Guluisun S. is the leader of the group. She is 53 and married. Her spouse earns his living by doing odd jobs. The family has two children. The elder daughter is a student, while the son is a schoolboy. The main source of the family’s income comes from their own grocery shop. All family members are drawn into this kind of business. This decision had been accepted five years ago after Guluisun's sister advised them to open a shop. Out of the profits, they have managed to make house repairs, to give an education to the daughter and to obtain a car. The loan's purpose is to expand the assortment of inventory with soft drinks, juice and detergents. In the future, the family is planning to give a proper upbringing to the children and to widen the shop. Shada E., 51, is divorced. Her only child, a son, works as a driver. Shada herself makes her bread by selling sunflower seeds, chewing gum, and cigarettes in the center of Kant. She gets some help from her son and his wife. Out of the profits, she has managed to purchase household appliances and to give an education to her grandchildren. The loan's purpose is to buy several kilograms of sunflower seeds and different sorts of cigarettes. In the future, Shada is planning to buy a new house. Janylkan J. is the treasurer of the group. She is 54 and a widow. She has three children: Both daughters are married, while the son raises money by working as a builder in Kant city and as a security guard in the medical institute. The main source of income she gets is from trading as Janylkan sells sunflower seeds, cigarettes, chewing gum, cookies and so on. Moreover, she breeds cattle and is paid a pension. Due to these activities, she has managed to arrange her son’s wedding and to make house renovations. The loan's purpose is to purchase a calf for fattening. In the future, she is planning to obtain a car and to build or purchase a new house. Galya M., 54, is married. The couple is already pensioners, but still the family raises money by farming. Fifteen years ago, Galya’s husband was a herder. His cattle business was started from one cow. Since that, they have bred cattle. Besides this, Galya earns additional income by working as a seamstress. The loan's purpose is to purchase a calf for to increase cattle stock. In the future, the family is planning to arrange their daughter’s wedding, to buy a car and to give a proper upbringing to the grandchildren. Where Did This Loan Come From? This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused microfinance institution in Kyrgyzstan. MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple "P" bottom line – People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only microfinance institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about MBF and view a video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135 If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loans.use: To purchase convenience goods

loans.name: God Grace Group

texts.en:
Marthina J., who is holding the sign, is the leader of this group of five borrowers called God Grace Group. She is 25 years old and married. She has three children whose ages are between 3 and 9 years. She was only able to attend school through sixth grade due to lack of financial support. 

For three years, she has been selling rice, cooking oil, salt, seasoning, pepper, etc., in Congo Town on the outskirts of Monrovia, Liberia. She plans to use her 6,000-Liberian-Dollars portion of this 30,000-Liberian-Dollars group loan to buy more rice, cooking oil, salt, seasoning, pepper, etc.
 
She describes herself as a determined woman whose dream is to improve her business and continue to educate her children so that they can have a better future.

loans.use: To buy more rice, cooking oil, salt, seasonings, pepper, etc.

loans.name: Jazgul's Group

texts.en:
Jazgul M., 27, is the leader of the group. She is married and has three children, the oldest of whom is in school. Her husband works at a building site. The family makes their living by selling cattle Two years ago, they had took out a loan so they could begin their own business. During these years, they have managed to improve their housing conditions. Jazgul’s family hopes to get a loan so they can buy hay for the cattle. In the future, they want to increase cattle stock. 

Ryskul S., 33, is the treasurer of the group. She is married and has four sons: the eldest one is a college student and the rest are schoolboys. The family's main income comes from cattle breeding. In addition, her husband makes 5,000 soms per month as a tractor operator. Out of their profits, they have managed to make house repairs. Ryskul wants a loan to purchase five livestock animals. In the future, they want to open their own shop.

Adilet M., 27, is married and has has three children (two sons and a daughter, all of whom are of preschool age). Adilet’s husband is a taxi-driver who makes 10,000 soms per month. The family also breeds cattle. They will use this loan to buy hay for cattle feeding and to buy car spare parts. 

Medin S., 46, is married and has three children. His wife, makes 4,500 soms a month working in an archival depository. The eldest son raises money by working in “Dordoi” company, the second son is a schoolboy, and the daughter is a seamstress. Ten years ago, they used a loan to purchase seven livestock animals, and they have run this business since then. During the years of working hard, they have managed to make repairs to their house. 

--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious, and socially-focused microfinance Institution in Kyrgyzstan. 
MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line:
• People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), 
• Planet (keeping environmentally friendly) 
• Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). 

MBF is the only microfinance Institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about MBF and view a video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135 
If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members receive special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loans.use: to purchase hay for cattle

loans.name: Alice Wanja

texts.en:
Alice, 35, has been rearing chicken in Naivasha town for the last four years.  She is married to Dominic Michuki, and they have two children.

Alice was introduced to KADET  LTD by her friend, and this will be her first loan. She plans to use the cash to buy more chicks to rear and sell.

Alice is planning to buy her own incubator in the near future so she can hatch her own eggs and start selling the chicks.

loans.use: To buy chicks

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: To buy bags of rice, tomatoes, beans, red oil, salt, and so forth

loans.name: Atyrkul's Group

texts.en:
Atyrkul O., 39, is the group leader. She is married and has three children. The oldest two are in school and the third is a toddler. Atyrkul and her husband breed cattle. Fourteen years ago, they borrowed potato seeds and learned how to cultivate land. This is now the main source of their income. They have managed to increase their cattle stock. They will use 12,000 soms of this loan to purchase cattle and 5,000 soms for their crops. 

Azat T., 38, is married. He has two sons, the elder one is a schoolboy. The family earns their living by cultivating different sorts of plants. Seven years ago, Azat was a builder, but then decided to start his own business. He grew wheat and potato,  and the harvest made a good profit for him. Since then, he has been developing this business. The loan purpose is to purchase solar oil for harvesting and to order tractor service. In the future, Azat wants to build a house. 

Nurhamida M., 35, is the treasurer of the group. She and her husband, who is a taxi-driver, have two children (the elder daughter is a schoolgirl). They have their own business where they sell pears and apples. Previously, they raised and sold cattle and used the profits to start their business., which they have had for seven years. Their earnings made it possible to buy a car. Nurhamida wants a loan so she can buy one young animal (10,000 soms) and two sheep (5,000 soms). In the future, the family is planning to build a house.

Dinara D., 32, is married and has three children. Her husband is an electric welder in Bishkek. He makes 10,000 soms a month. The family runs their own business: they have land, which has been cultivated for three years. Out of the profits, they have managed to buy household appliances. The loan purpose is to purchase coal for winter (1,5 tons). In the future, Dinara’s family hopes to build a new house and to increase cattle stock.

--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious, and socially-focused microfinance Institution in Kyrgyzstan. 
MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line:
• People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), 
• Planet (keeping environmentally friendly) 
• Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). 

MBF is the only microfinance Institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about MBF and view a video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135 
If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members receive special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loans.use: To purchase cattle

loans.name: Aida's Group

texts.en:
Aida M. is the leader of this group. She is 32 and married. Her husband is a builder. They have three children, the eldest of which are in school. Two years ago they started their own business under favorable conditions: they had an available countryside tillage, which had been used for sowing. Aida also earns money by working as a school teacher. She has managed to get education (she has almost finished her study on correspondence basis). The family hopes to get a loan to buy coal. In the future they plan to build a new house and to purchase a car.

Venera K., 33, is married. Her husband is a farmer and she is a nurse, but their main source of income is farming. They have three children, all of whom are in school. They will use the loan to buy seasonal (autumn and winter) clothing for their children. In the future, they plan to widen their house or build a new one. 

Kenjebek K., 42, is married. He has three children. He has bred cattle for four years. He makes additional income by working as a taxi driver. His wife is a private entrepreneur. Their hard work has enabled them to buy a car. They will use the loan to make car repairs.  Kenjebek wants to give his children a proper education, make house repairs, and buy a new car.

Jumakul S., 52, is the treasurer of the group. She is a widow who is raising two daughters by herself. Both girls are in school. Her son is married. Jumakul earns her livelihood by working in laundry. She needs a loan to give her daughters a good education. In the future, she plans to build a new house.

Altynbek M., 41,  is married. He has three sons, all of whom are in school. Altynbek supports his family by working in a fire company and by driving a taxi. His wife is a private entrepreneur. He wants to get a loan to use in commodity circulation. In the future, he wants to purchase a seven-passenger car.

--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious, and socially-focused microfinance Institution in Kyrgyzstan. 
MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line:
• People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), 
• Planet (keeping environmentally friendly) 
• Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). 

MBF is the only microfinance Institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about MBF and view a video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135 
If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members receive special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loans.use: To buy more bags of flour, sugar and beans
